summary: This document is an FBI case file inventory (File 72-MM-113327) listing evidence and materials related to the investigation of Alfredo Rodriguez, an associate of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes evidence receipts, consent forms, correspondence, and a list of items seized or obtained, such as passports, monitored phone calls, and a letter from attorney Bradley Edwards requesting information about Epstein's activities. This document is an FBI evidence receipt form (FD-340) for original notes from an interview of an unnamed individual, along with attached subpoena materials and AT&T subscriber records. It includes a grand jury subpoena for phone records (number 305-302-5548) and invoices related to a $50,000 wire transfer. The document shows law enforcement gathering financial and communication evidence in the Epstein investigation. This is an AT&T invoice detailing call and data usage for a specific account number over multiple billing cycles from August to November 2009. It shows numerous calls, including many international calls to Bolivia, and domestic calls to locations like Dayton, Miami, and Jasper. The document is a billing record that could be used to establish communication patterns. This document is an AT&T telephone invoice (account number 718920) for the billing cycle October 4, 2009, to November 7, 2009. It details numerous calls, many to locations in Jasper, AL, and other cities, with zero charges, suggesting it may be a record of call activity for an account associated with the investigation. This document appears to be a certification page from an FBI file, likely part of a response to a grand jury subpoena served on Verizon California, Inc. (GTE). It certifies that attached documents are responsive to the subpoena and is executed under penalty of perjury. This document is a collection of evidence receipts, subpoena notices, and phone records related to an FBI investigation. It includes a subpoena from the U.S. Attorney's Office for records to be produced to a grand jury, a receipt for property seized from Alfredo Rodriguez, and extensive Verizon and Sprint phone billing records for multiple numbers and addresses in California and Nevada from 2004-2006.

connections.description: Rodriguez was an employee/associate of Epstein, as indicated by references to his salary being paid by Epstein's company and his possession of information about Epstein's activities.
Attorney Edwards corresponded with Rodriguez to obtain information and documents for a civil case against Epstein, indicating Rodriguez was a potential witness.
Edwards was an attorney representing a plaintiff (Jane Doe) in a civil case against Epstein, as indicated in the correspondence letterhead.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, an associate of Jeffrey Epstein, was the subject of an FBI investigation (File 72-MM-113327) and his property, including passports and an address book, was seized.

Attorney Bradley Edwards sought extensive information from Rodriguez for a civil case against Epstein, including names of masseuses/victims, Epstein's company details, club memberships, and a confidentiality agreement.
Evidence includes consensually monitored phone calls with Alfredo Rodriguez (7 discs) and his deposition from August 2009.
The document inventory shows law enforcement obtained Rodriguez's phone records, magicJack VoIP account details, and a signed consent to search.
A federal grand jury subpoena was issued for all subscriber and detailed billing information for cellular telephone number (305) 302-5548 from July 1, 2009.
The FBI evidence form indicates possession of 'original notes re interview' of an individual whose name is not fully legible in the provided text.
An invoice shows a transaction related to a $50,000 outgoing wire transfer, with a fee billed to Alfredo Rodriguez.
Multiple AT&T subscriber records were provided in response to the subpoena, showing accounts with Miami, FL addresses and service suspensions for non-payment in October 2009.
The document includes a non-disclosure notice warning the recipient not to disclose the existence of the subpoena to avoid obstructing the investigation.
The document is an AT&T invoice dated March 11, 2010, covering billing cycles from August to November 2009.
It records numerous international calls to Bolivia, with associated charges, interspersed with many domestic calls.
The invoice is addressed to 'Nana', who appears to be the account holder or recipient.
The record includes both voice call details and data transfer logs, providing a comprehensive communication log.
The document is a financial record that could be used to trace communication patterns and locations during the specified time periods.
The document is an AT&T invoice dated March 11, 2010, for account number 718920.
The billing cycle covered is October 4, 2009, to November 7, 2009.
The call detail shows numerous calls to Jasper, AL, and other locations, all with $0.00 charges.
The document is marked as proprietary and for authorized use only, not for general distribution.
The repetitive calls to specific locations like Jasper, AL, may indicate a pattern of communication relevant to the investigation.
A grand jury subpoena was served on Verizon California, Inc. (GTE), indicating a legal investigation involving telecommunications records.
The certification was executed on or around April 1, 2010, under penalty of perjury, confirming the responsiveness of attached documents to the subpoena.
The document is part of FBI records (EFTA00129883), suggesting federal law enforcement involvement in the investigation.
The U.S. Attorney's Office issued a grand jury subpoena with a non-disclosure notice, warning against revealing the request to avoid obstructing the investigation.
Extensive Verizon phone records (Case #10264355000) detail calls from 2004-2006 associated with addresses in Santa Monica, Malibu, Los Alamitos, and Huntington Beach, California.
Sprint subscriber information reveals an account in the name of Joseph Alvarez for a phone number (702-743-0620) with an address history linking Henderson, NV, to New York, NY.
An FBI evidence receipt shows property (a card and keys) was seized from Alfredo Rodriguez.
The document indicates the investigation involved seeking phone records from multiple carriers (Verizon, Sprint) covering a multi-year period (2004-2006).
